summary: An FBI Miami Division request to the Document Conversion Laboratory (DocLab) for scanning and automation assistance regarding telephone records in the obstruction of justice case against Alfredo Rodriguez, Jeffrey Epstein's former house manager. The records are from an address book Rodriguez possessed, believed to contain contact information for additional underage victims of Epstein, which he attempted to sell.

persons.name: Alfredo Rodriguez
persons.role: Subject of obstruction of justice investigation, former house manager and butler to Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: The subject of the FBI's obstruction of justice case. He was Epstein's former house manager and butler who came into possession of an address book believed to contain names and numbers of additional underage victims, which he attempted to sell.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.role: Subject of a child prostitution case
persons.context: Referenced as the subject of a child prostitution case for whom Rodriguez worked. The address book in Rodriguez's possession is believed to contain information related to Epstein's underage victims.

connections.description: Rodriguez was the former house manager and butler to Jeffrey Epstein.
Rodriguez possessed an address book believed to contain information on Epstein's underage victims, connecting him to the broader criminal activity.

events.title: FBI opens obstruction case against Rodriguez
events.description: Miami Division opened an obstruction of justice case against Alfredo Rodriguez.

events.title: Timeframe for telephone records review
events.description: Telephone records generated between September 1, 2001, and the present (June 2010) are prioritized for scanning and analysis in the investigation.

events.title: Rodriguez attempts to sell victim address book
events.description: Alfredo Rodriguez attempted to sell an address book containing names and numbers of potential underage victims of Jeffrey Epstein to an Undercover Employee (UCE), rather than turning it over to law enforcement or attorneys in response to federal subpoenas.

keyFacts: Alfredo Rodriguez, Jeffrey Epstein's former house manager and butler, was under FBI investigation for obstruction of justice for attempting to sell an address book believed to contain contact information for additional, previously unknown underage victims of Epstein.

The FBI was processing telephone records (target number 340-771-2680) from the address book, believed to belong to Epstein, his associates, or potential underage victims, for incorporation into its Telephone Application (TA) investigative database.

The document is a formal FBI request (Baleen Sweep case) for the Document Conversion Laboratory to scan and automate these telephone records to aid the investigation, indicating the records were considered important evidence.
Rodriguez's attempt to sell the book occurred during pending civil litigation related to Epstein, and he failed to comply with federal subpoenas demanding its turnover.
